conclusion: The problem involves analyzing a v-t graph to determine scenarios where a particle passes through a certain position three times within the time interval [0, t₁].
The graph shows velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis, is symmetric about a dashed vertical line, starts positive, becomes negative, and then positive again.
The time interval under consideration is from 0 to t₁.
When v > 0, the particle moves in the positive direction; when v < 0, it moves in the negative direction.
The displacement is equal to the net area under the v-t curve, with the area above the t-axis representing positive displacement and the area below representing negative displacement.
The U-shaped velocity curve indicates the particle starts with a positive velocity, decelerates to zero, continues with negative velocity, and then accelerates back to positive velocity.
For a particle to pass through the same position three times in [0, t₁], it must move away from that position, return to it, move away again, and return to it again.

If the reference position P is the initial position (at t=0), the particle starts at P with positive velocity, moves away, returns to P after accumulating negative displacement, continues with negative velocity, and then positive velocity, returning to P again if the net displacement to t₁ is zero.

If the reference position P is a position the particle reaches after t=0, the particle starts elsewhere, reaches P for the first time, moves away, returns to P, moves away again, and returns to P again.
For position P to be passed three times, there must exist times t₁, t₂, t₃ such that A(t₁) = A(t₂) = A(t₃), where A(t) is the area under the curve representing displacement.
The particle must initially be moving in the positive direction, then reverse direction when v becomes negative, and reverse direction again when v becomes positive.

Possible scenarios include: (1) The particle starts at the reference position, moves away, returns to it, moves away again, and then returns again. (2) The particle starts elsewhere, reaches the reference position, leaves it, returns to it, leaves it again, and returns again.

For this to happen, the reference position must be chosen such that the net displacement from the starting point to that position equals the net displacement at two other points within the time interval.
